abstract_summ: After adjustment for ACS NSQIP-estimated probabilities of morbidity or mortality, no geriatric-specific preoperative risk factors were significantly associated with increased risk of death or complications in any age group (all p > 0.055).We identified patients at a high risk of FTR by analyzing laboratory findings, complication data, intensive care unit records, and risk scoring including Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE) IV, Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score, and Simplified Acute Physiology Score (SAPS) 3 at ICU admission.The preoperative sCr and CPB time are independent risk factors for postoperative CRRT patients.In addition, the registry demonstrates that the provision of cardiac surgery in Germany is up to date, appropriate, and nationwide patient treatment is guaranteed all the time.It showed that preoperative sCr and CPB time were independent risk factors for CRRT patients undergoing surgery for TA-AAD.
title_summ: Predictive risk factors for postoperative pneumonia after heart transplantationThe effect of patent ductus arteriosus on coronary artery blood flow in premature infants: a prospective observational pilot studyFrailty Predicts Morbidity and Mortality After Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy for Acute Cholecystitis: An ACS-NSQIP Cohort AnalysisLonger term hemodialysis-dependent chronic renal failure increases the risk of post-cardiac surgery vasoplegic syndromePrediction of Postoperative Mortality in Patients with Organ Failure After Gastric Cancer SurgerySafety of Major Abdominal Operations in the Elderly: A Study of Geriatric-Specific Determinants of HealthIndependent risk factors and the long-term outcomes for postoperative continuous renal replacement treatment in patients who underwent emergency surgery for type a acute aortic dissectionOptimizing classical risk scores to predict complications in head and neck surgery: a new approachThe effects of body mass index on outcomes for patients undergoing surgical aortic valve replacementAdjusted preoperative variables to predict perioperative red blood cell transfusion in coronary artery bypass grafting.Predictors of in-hospital mortality in patients with left ventricular assist device.German Heart Surgery Report 2019:The Annual Updated Registry of the German Society for Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery.
title_abstract_phrases: We identified patients at a high risk of FTR by analyzing laboratory findings, complication data, intensive care unit records, and risk scoring including Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE) IV, Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score, and Simplified Acute Physiology Score (SAPS) 3 at ICU admission.After adjustment for ACS NSQIP-estimated probabilities of morbidity or mortality, no geriatric-specific preoperative risk factors were significantly associated with increased risk of death or complications in any age group (all p > 0.055).CONCLUSION: Overweight and obese patients should be considered as readily for AVR as normal BMI patients.In addition, the registry demonstrates that the provision of cardiac surgery in Germany is up to date, appropriate, and nationwide patient treatment is guaranteed all the time.Optimizing classical risk scores to predict complications in head and neck surgery: a new approachPURPOSE: To validate tools to identify patients at risk for perioperative complications to implement prehabilitation programmes in head and neck surgery (H&N).
